description:
Solid and super affordable burrito joint on Mission just south of 16th. 

I got a super burrito with chicken ($10.99). They grill the tortilla with cheese and meat to get the outside slightly crisp and melt the cheese, its the best way to do it. Super had fresh bright green avocado, beans, sour cream, and not too much rice. Meat was rich and moist, unlike the bland and chewy chicken you are often stuck with in inferior establishments.

My buddy got a vegetarian burrito. All the same stuff with no meat for $8.99.

The green salsa from the hot sauce bar was dope. Nice and spicy. Bar also has chips, jalapenos, spicy pickles, and red salsa.

Its a no-frills place that is low-key awesome. Grab one before heading to Uptown for a cheap IPA and thank the gods that there is still cheap good stuff in SF in 2018.
author: Phood E.

description:
This place is getting a two star because I bit into a big fat chunk of bone or tough tendon in my quesadilla "el Castillito". If that weren't the case, it would have gotten a solid 3. The quesadilla (or is it pastor?) comes on the VERY GREASY side, so this thing was literally dripping oil as I attempted to eat it. Not a really good experience when I'm eating a quesadilla, or anything for that matter lmao.

So yeah this rating is based almost entirely on my experience with the food here. Other things about the establishment including service, friendliness, cleanliness, condiment bar are pretty much on par with other Mission taquerías, at least as far as I'm concerned. Price point is also pretty similar - the quesadilla I got was $11-12. The regular burrito is about $9-10. 

Wouldn't come back. Tough life being in such a competitive area for taquerías.
author: Brian W.

description:
My mistake may have been ordering tacos instead of a burrito, which seems to get more play here. The tacos were definitely good, but there was nothing special about the meat, tortillas, or the sauce. To be honest, I liked other things about the place more:
- vertigo vibe, with a TV in the corner playing spanish-language news at full volume, which is competing with giant speakers in the middle of the room blaring boleros. kinda loved it.
- the free chips & salsas (plural) station in the corner, near the counter. And these were actually good chips. Compare this to paying for mediocre chips and guac in New York...
- staff who didn't mind that an apparently homeless man had decided to rest, after eating a taco, in the restaurant. This is a good thing.
author: Jacob H.

description:
Prawn Super Taco is very substantial ... tortilla, cheese, 8 shrimp, rice, beans, avocado, pico de Gallo, and sour cream. You can make a light meal out of it and it's $6.99! I'm particularly impressed with the volume of shrimp, and they had a great smoky flavor. 

For hungrier people, prawn wet burrito is $12.99 and is enormous. 

The green sauce is really tasty. Red sauce is good too.
author: Julia C.

description:
This was the busiest place when I was scoping out taquerias in the Mission. So I stopped in and got two tacos: carne asada and pastor. I liked both a lot lot lot. 

They have a salsa bar with free chips. The chips aren't the traditional greasy ones. I didn't really like them but thought it was nice that they served them at the bar. 

I will be back to try more things on the menu for sure.
author: AnneMarie W.

description:
Got here last Wednesday at 7 pm and there were only two guests at this restaurant. My friend and I were really impressed to see how slow it was for a joint located in such a good area. We ate our food very slowly (it took over an hour till we were done) and surprisingly we saw virtually ZERO guests walking in. It's hard to understand how this place will remain open for business.

Our food was fine (I got a burrito mojado) and my friend got two tacos. The staff was friendly, the food was ready within minutes and the restaurant was shining clean. Prices were average and it was a nice evening to be out, so it was hard to tell why nobody cared for this place.
author: Mariana C.

description: This is a great super burrito. Local spot with real avocado, excellent meat, and my favorite carnitas on the Mission strip.
author: Zachary L.

description:
We came into the Mission last week for one thing, and one thing only: an Al Pastor Burrito from El Castillito. Reading an old copy of Bon Appetit, El Castillito was praised as having "the best burrito" ever eaten by the author, Gustavo Arellano (who you should get to know if you haven't) and David Chang (?!). I'd never even heard of this place! 

As a Bay Area native, I've frequented El Faro, El Farolito, La Taqueria, etc. my entire life, and realized that I've never crowned any specific taqueria with "Best Burrito." As far as burritos go, I'm a simpleton - I came into adulthood eating $2 BCR's (bean, cheese, rice) from Cinco de Mayo in Concord. I reserve judgments for rellenos and enchiladas. Burritos are almost always two thumbs up.

Either way, curiosity got the best of me, and we braved the post-apocalyptic hell that is the 16th St. BART station to get to this place. El Castillito is your classic hole in the wall - bright yellow walls, a couple guys running the place that are laid back and casual, insane piles of carnitas and asada being grilled on the flattop in back. Folks wheeling their bikes in and hanging out...the usual.

We ordered just one Al Pastor (pork) Super Burrito ($10) - rice, pinto beans, cheese, meat, chunky guac, a bit of sour cream. Just your classic burrito, with free chips (unfortunately not freshly fried) and salsa bar (2 salsas - tomatillo and tomato-based, both pretty mild). 

Bigger than your average forearm, the size, filling distribution, and overall quality of the burrito is indeed 5 stars. It's a great burrito, and you'd be a fool for passing it up if you're in the area. I hope that's the only convincing you need. 

General cleanliness, ambiance, and overall vibe leaves a bit to be desired, but the burritos are definitely top notch. Definitely not a date night spot, but worth a stop if you're on a bar crawl or your own burrito quest. Godspeed!
author: Laura B.

description: Carne asada super burritos used to be really good, but something's changed.  Also, they've raised their prices. $12 for a super burrito.. I can get a much better burrito at the taco truck on 16&Shotwell for nearly half their price!
author: David G.

description: Ordered a carnitas burrito. Really delicious. Didn't feel heavy. Meat was really tasty. They only have 2 salsas, green and red, but very fresh and potent. New fav in mission
author: Pramod G.

description:
Hello 4th time coming here ! The cashier/Cook ( Angel ) is awsome!!!
I love how he cooks !!! I only ask him to cook for me !!! He makes the best food he's clean and nice! 
The others look sketchy, but angel (tall guy with hair slicked back) he is the best!!!
author: Angelo W.

description: Bomb! Service was friendly (unusual for a taqueria) and fast. My order was correct and soooo good.
author: Jesus A.

description: Food was delicious! Tried the torta de jamón and they added everything a torta needs to have to be complete. The staff really friendly and had great service.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
One of the better Taqueria's in my opinion.

Not only is the staff really friendly, the food is amazing. And next to that their salsabar is perfect. Salsabar is one of more important things that make a taqueria really good. 
The super burrito is always perfect, started eating quesedilla's more and this is AMAZING
author: Styn V.

description:
You had me at tacos al pastor. Juicy and delicious!

Super casual Taqueria in SF's Mission District, on the same block as the 16th St BART station. Not crowded, not pretentious, but simply good Mexican food. 
Todos en Español. 
Don't change.
author: Jason T.

description: Meh food, and worse, faked a 40+% tip. Appalling.
author: R I.

description:
Simply disgusting. 

Ordering takeout? Think again. They'll put literal scraps in your food. Stay away, even if it's a last resort.
author: Julia N.

description:
This is a first impression, first time visit review. Myself and a friend were actually trying to eat at La Oaxaqueña but their kitchen is closed Mondays (who knew). We were super hungry and my friend suggested we try the taqueria el castillito because it was honestly the closest place and why not. 

tl;dr: eat here. it was freaking amazing. the tortilla was great, the rice was effing perfect, and I would literally take a cup of refried beans to go just to drink it down, because yes, it was all that good.

For one - it was empty except for a few customers. To me, this is a good thing, especially when a Mexican joint has Hispanic/Mexican customers + locals. They take card - so we ordered and didn't wait very long at all. I got the bean and rice burrito, my friend ended up getting the two tacos plate with beef tacos or something and eventually getting a shrimp taco. 
For two - we did not wait long AT ALL. It was great! The cashier was being super patient with me because I was trying to overcomplicate my order and he was trying to help me out.
For three - the food was so good. It was just so good. I asked for no onions and cilantro on the side of my burrito (because I hate cilantro tbh). When I got my burrito...me and my friend asked for sour cream and I put a Little bit on my second bite then added a pinch of *very well diced* cilantro. I ended up running out of cilantro and contemplating eating a second burrito. It was sooo damn good. 

Did I mention how good it was??
author: Nyah B.

description:
Nice place and staff, food was solid but nothing special. 

Walking in, the seating area was open and pleasant for my group. I ordered my taco go-to, al pastor. However, it looked pretty dry and not marinated, as opposed to typical al pastor which I was a bit disappointed with - ended up not being as flavorful as comparable tacos. However, you can tell everything is very fresh, and grilled right in front of you. 

Open season on the chips and salsa bar at the side is always a plus ;)
author: Chandrabh A.

description: I was looking for some breakfast early in the morning and decided to try this place. I think that this place deserves 5 stars to the amazing staff. They are so nice and make you feel like right at home. The lady helping me was so sweet and took her time with me on deciding what I wanted. Also the food was good. I ordered a carne asada place and salsa and must say it was good.
author: Jorge T.

description:
If this isn't the best taqueria within walking distance of my home, it comes pretty close. The burritos are always delicious, the meat always plentiful, and the staff always happy to help. The décor's lacking, but it could be much worse--and $10 here will fill you up for a day and a half.

I've been going here for months, and I've never left unsatisfied.
author: Amitabho C.

description: I have been going here since Before Bill Clinton was president. Absolutely, for me, the perfect burrito. I make special trips now from Seattle to visit. That's not BS.
author: Anthony S.

description: I had 2 al pastor tacos.  While they were great, they weren't red which makes me think they are not quite authentic.
author: David N.

description: In a sea of fast food Mexican fast food restaurants in this city, this one stands out the most. The place is pretty much what you expect from a taqueria, but the staff is super friendly and the food on the other hand is amazing. Try the carnitas burrito or the burrito al pastor.
author: J H.

description: This place was on a list of "one of the best burritos." I thought that it certainly was a good balanced burrito, but was just okay. It is close to a BART stop which is nice, but in a more dingy area of the Mission. Try not to sit too close to the door or someone may come in and ask you for money. It was not a scary area, but maybe a tourist who is not used to homeless people may be alarmed by it. There are so many other taquerias in the area, that there would be  no need for me to visit it again. Same prices as Chipotle. I like supporting a mom-and-pop any day over Chipotle, but $7 for a burrito seemed a bit much for me. It is an okay option, but far from the "best" burrito as the article I read stated.
author: Sunny D.

description:
I don't know where all the five-stars come from, but the super carne asada burrito I had last night wasn't anything worth going back and getting again.

The meat tasted pretty good, but everything else was bland.  

The salsas were laughable.  The red salsa tasted like tomato puree and the green salsa tasted like vinegar.

It may have been a one-time fluke, but thanks anyways.  You can keep your tiny castle.

Go to La Taqueria or Farolito.
author: John M.

description: I'm glad I tried this place before looking at yelp, they fantastic. The place itself is pretty gross but tacos a great. :)
author: Jennifer T.

description:
At 3pm on a Monday this place is not very crowded. Good thing because I did not know what the ordering process was.

1) Order at the counter in back
2) Pick up your own chips off the counter
3) Get your salsa from the salsa bar
4) Wait at your table, your order will be brought out to you
5) When finished, bus your own table - garbage, bins in the back

I got the regular burrito with carne asada. My initial impression was that the ingredients were good but the burrito was a little dry - I could use some more of that spicy salsa. However, the tortilla was toasted awesomeness. Flakey and crispy on the outside. Not gummy at all.

Chips were okay. Salsa was okay.

I wasn't able to finish the regular burrito - maybe ate 60%? But leftovers the next day were just as good. Tortilla stayed crispy. Flavors and moisture melded together a bit so didn't think it was dry now.

I'll have to go back to try the Al Pastor super burrito.
author: Jean K.

description:
Check out the review that was given to Taquerilla castillito in the national blog
http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/our-correspondent-laments-the-burrito-that-got-away/
author: Oscar A.

description:
Their quesadilla is the best in the neighborhood. They layer the ingredients well before toasting it on the griddle. When you eat it, you get all the tastes in every bite. 

I hate getting a burrito where the meat is on one side, the guacamole on the other. These guys get how to do it right.
author: Nilay P.

description:
Food is good so the two stars are for that. 

Where they lose major points is the purposefully vague way they handle their menu. This was the third occasion I paid almost $10 for what should have been $4-$5. 

Allow me to explain: 

They offer a "regular" nachos and a "super" nachos. They're only $1 different in price, but the super has just about everything on it, including choice of meat. You might ask "who would opt for the cheaper one, when the super is practically the same price?" Well, usually I just want something lighter, so it's what I lean toward. The first time I got that, while making it, the guy behind the counter asked what meat I wanted. I clarified, "oh, it comes with meat? I thought it was just beans, cheese and jalapeños.." He said "yeah, meat if you want it". Awesome. That kinda makes sense, since it's almost as expensive as the super. I add chicken. Then, am summarily charged for the super. "I asked for the regular nachos", I begin to say. "Oh, no, you added chicken, that's the super". Allow me to ponder, then, why the hell I asked them that question 45 seconds prior. 

Time after that, similar instance, but now that I'm savvy to the system, I want the regular nachos, and almost ask if I can add avocado - assuming I'll be charged an extra dollar or two - quickly realizing, it's probably cheaper to order the super, minus everything but avocado. Aha! Genius! So I plainly say that I want what's on the regular, plus avocado, so to please make an order of the super, no meat, no other extras. The cashier asks "oh.. do you want the regular?" I explain my rationale, saying it appears cheaper to do this, versus an add-on of avocado. She clarifies, "so, just beans, cheese, jalapeños and avavado?" Precisely! Oh but wait.. I'm still charged for the regular + add-on avavado. Apparently her clarification was actually an attempt at upselling. 

Now, you're probably thinking.. Who cares? It's take out food, not a mission to Mars. True. Very true. But there's something just so irritating about stopping by for a late night nosh, specifying what you want, double checking it with the cashier, and getting charged extra. 

And just tonight, a mere moment ago, I ordered the "flour tortilla and cheese" quesadilla. She keys in the order, I add "oh, uh, may I add a side of rice?" reading from the board marked "Extras". She asks if I want rice added into the quesadilla, or on the side, and I just say "on the side is fine". I hand her a $10, for the $3.99 quesadilla and $1.50 side of rice and get handed back to $1 bills. 

A moment passes and I think "did I do it again, did I fuck up this ultra simple order? Am I back in this Bermuda Triangle of add-ons?" 

I ask the cashier "pardon me, how much was the total?" She looks down at the keys of the register to jog her memory and says "quesadilla was $4, rice on the side is $4".

"I thought it's $1.50", pointing, "on the 'Extras' menu?" She begins to ask "did you want rice *in* the quesadilla or *next to* the quesadilla? 

I pause... what the hell is the difference? 

"Umm.. On the side? I just wanted what's on the menu for $1.50" 

"Yes but you want a side of rice, that's extra. Those items (on the Extras menu) are for extras added to it, like if you were adding rice to a burrito it's $1.50 but if you want rice next to it that's different" 

"Alright.." becoming hopeful that she hears herself and realizes how dumb this all sounds, and offers to give me back the difference, "I asked for a side of rice, which is on the menu for $1.50, (now really annoyed) where on the menu does it even say that rice is also available for $4?" 

She smiled sheepishly, repeating her explanation about how the geographical location of the rice dictates a near $3 differential in price. 

Part of me wanted to cancel the order, ask for my money back, and leave on my apparently misguided principle that when someone orders off the menu, they're charged the goddamn menu price. But that would have meant I paused House of Cards and put on pants all in vein. 

I waited for my $8 box of tortilla, cheese and rice, pondering that eternal question: do I feel petty enough to leave a poor Yelp review? 

Yes, I say now, proudly. And even though my quesadilla is cold I feel slightly better about myself. And that's worth at least $4.
author: Scott R.

description: Favorite taqueria in SF... by a huge margin. Such good meat. Extremely nice staff. The green salsa is out of this world.
author: Ellen D.

description:
After a night of drinking at Zeitgeist, we were desperate for some cheap, late night munchies. Thanks to Yelp, we found El Castillito and made the trek over (at 2am through the Mission...yeah, we were really hungry). 

The small restaurant was packed to the brim, and although they were in semi-closing mode, they were still serving food. 

Everything we ordered was HUGE. Their wet burrito is one of the biggest and most impressive i've seen, and looked absolutely delicious (although I doubt my friend felt very good the next day...you know what beer and copious amounts of Mexican food will do to one's insides...). 

My quesadilla was really big and tasty, although these are difficult to screw up. Another plus was the red salsa - highly recommended. Went great with the quesadilla and wasn't too spicy. 

Cool spot. Would recommend for late night eats.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Let me start by saying that my food was good, and when I ordered it, the service was good.

Let me follow that up by saying that I expect a business I am patronizing to prioritize my safety over the interests of the local junkies.

I had a really messed up experience at this place tonight, and I am still upset and disturbed. To begin the ordeal, I bought my food, my boyfriend bought his and we enjoyed eating. That was all fine.

When I was done with my food I needed to use the restroom. I walked over to the women's restroom and saw the switch said occupied, so I knocked gently to let the person inside know someone was waiting.

Several minutes later a woman emerged, and I recognized her from 20 minutes or so prior when we walked past her panhandling on Mission. She mumbled something at me and walked off. I began to enter the bathroom to see a man standing in there. I told him I needed to use the bathroom and he informed me, with words and gestures, that he was not going to leave because he was planning on smoking in there.

I don't know if he meant weed or tobacco or crack, but clearly he did not want to leave. I told him several times that I needed to use the toilet and he demonstrated to me that he did not plan to exit the bathroom to give me privacy. He had every intent to stand there in the bathroom and watch me pee, because he needed to smoke whatever it was he wanted to smoke.

I had to go to the cashier and tell him what was happening to get him to make the guy leave the single stall women's bathroom. I immediately ducked into the bathroom and locked the door. What happened after that I know only because my native Spanish speaking boyfriend relayed it to me.

Apparently this guy was friends with the staff, and when he was told to leave the bathroom he started spouting all kinds of profanity about me. He referred to me as a whore. The whole ordeal seemed to be a joke to him in the staff.

Let me reiterate:

1. I bought food here.
2. I needed to use a bathroom I had every reason to believe I should be able to use.
3. There was a creepy man in there who refused to let me pee without standing there and watching me, because he wanted to smoke something and apparently that was more important.
4. When he was finally told to get out and let me use the bathroom, he called me a whore, among other things.
5. He is friends with the staff, and they stood around laughing together about this.

3 hours later, I am still upset about it. Definitely won't be returning to a restaurant that cares so little for its customers' safety and right to pee without being watched by a stranger. You messed up tonight, staff of Taqueria El Castillito.
author: MelanieBlau B.

description:
Really mediocre. Just bland. I had the wet burrito with chorizo, which at most places would be an intensely tasty item. It wasn't wet, it wasn't tasty - even after I added salsa. 


The mission has very good Mexican food. Don't waste your time here. Not really anything more to be said.

EDIT: except that the next morning I got a stomachache. Great. I should probably downgrade to 1 star...
author: Chris S.

description:
Forget the haters, this is my new favorite burrito place in the Bay.

Better than El Farolito, better than anything in East Oakland.

Like, JESUS CHRIST, they make a good burrito. The tortilla is very soft and fresh, and yet ever-so-slightly slightly grilled on the outside. Al pastor is tender and flavorful, guacamole is fresh, and the rice is soft and cheesy. It's so big you can take it home and eat the rest in your bed before taking a nap. (Seriously tho, f*cking do that, you will thank me).

You get an A+, El Castillito. 

They take cards and are riiiiiight by BART / the best intersection in all of San Francisco.
author: K M.

description: Cheerful enough service. Suspect low-cost ingredients of correspondingly low quality. Flan was chalky and room temp. Had to ask for sour cream with my huevos rancheros. It had little flavor and was sweeter than sour. Average at best.
author: Moses M.

description:
Taq. el Castillito is an old fashioned typical hole in the wall. open-grill taqueria

eats: lenguq burrito (5.60)
-nice flavorful corn chips
-tender not so flavorful lenqua, lots of it
-not much spiciness in burrito, ok but bland
-burrito pretty big
-3.5 stars

frijoles refritos:
-didn't see any salsa bar.
-burrito a 4 star value
-no upgrade since it was lacking that spicy punch.
-lots of sitdown room.
author: Victor G.

description:
This is a pretty sweet little find- a small no-frills style taqueria with no hype and big burritos. Compared to other on Mission they are just a bit pricey- but freshness is there and there is at least room to come in and sit down unlike my favorite spots that are like broom closets.
Take advantage of their salsa bar- very good mild and spicy homemade's as well as incredibly fresh tortillas. Not much to look at on the walls and the furniture could use help but really thats all part o he Mission experience. Solid food. Good prices. Great place.
author: Jack W.

description:
El Castillito has excellent super carne asada burritos.  I feel like their asada is more consistent than Cancun or El Farolito.  Having lettuce and tomato on a burrito is hit or miss, but El Castillito has been consistently good with fresh veggies.  Another plus, they have fresh avocado slices instead of nasty quacamole!

Their chips are homemade and delicious and most importantly FREE.  They have a salsa bar with a good selection.  Prices are on par with other taquerias in the area, and the portions are large.

It is open late and a block away from the 16th St. BART and bus hub.  Definitely worth a try whether on your lunch break or stumbling home from the bar!

Note: El Castillito is on the stretch of Mission between 16th and 17th (on the side of the street closer to Valencia).  This is where the crack dealers peddle their wares, so it is inevitably infested with crackheads and bums.  If this type of thing scares and disgusts you, do everyone a favor and just go back to Noe Valley or Pac Heights.  For everyone else, have your purse/wallet secure and use common sense and manners.
author: Lisa H.

description: I really enjoyed this place. We were searching for authentic Mexican food that wasn't packed and this place delivered fantastic food and a great atmosphere. The staff was super friendly and the cook accommodated my "no cheese or sour cream" request for my vegetarian taco. It came piled high with rice, beans, lettuce, avocado & a huge slice of tomato. Chips and salsa bar are complimentary and the prices to begin with are some of the least expensive I've seen on my trip. When we were eating, the majority of the restaurant was filled with people I'm assuming are locals so it must be a favorite stop. Great food, friendly staff and super great prices.
author: Maureen H.

description:
I go to this place more than any other taqueria in the Mission. It's right around the corner.  I like it better than Taqueria Cancun which is the most popular (and overrated) between 16th and 18t.  LA Oaxican once sold me a crunchy blue corn tortilla which was terrible and the vibe seems weird to me. 

I love the simple regular burrito or a dinner plate.  Good prices, CONSISTENT.  I can always cut my burrito in half and save the rest.  That alone earned the 5th star.  They also used to be in the Castro at 18th.  Solid.  If you are looking for flare try Los Coyotes taqueria.  More expensive and you won't get two meals our of the burrito.  

The staff is friendly and also pretty consistent.  I've been going for 5 years.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Looks & smells like little Mexico. Hot like Mexico. Nothing fancy but if you enjoy hot Mexican food for easy cash come here. Salsas are delicious. 
My mother didn't want to go through the door. shes a little delicate. After I pushed her in she settle down nicely. She said the refried beans were the best she's had in her life. However she thought the coffee was monstrous.
author: Dave Z.

description: The prawn burrito is one of the best in the city. The staff has always been friendly. That part of the mission can have some creepy folks, so I always take my food to go. Nothing fancy, but basic mexican food.
author: Fabian M.

description: Great place to randomly stop in before drinking at a foodless bar! Had a yummy veggie burrito and a beer. What more could you ask for?!
author: London R.

description: I had my pick of Mission-style Mexican, and I'm really glad I picked this place to walk into looking for lunch. I had a carne asada burrito, wet with mole colorado and salsa verde, and was totally pleased. It looks like they do everything well, all the staples of humble workingman's fare. The chips are fresh all day, and the complimentary salsas are spicy and frequently rotated. Everyone here was nice, and it always pleases me to find a true neighborhood joint.
author: Bill S.

description: You go here for the food and not to see the drug addicts and zombies.This place has been around for over 20 years. This place is a classic taqueria which is over shadowed in a two block radius from places like La Cumbre, Pancho Villa, El Toro and every other Taqueria in the Mission District. Do not bring your date here.
author: Juan V.

description: They have the best wet burritos there and their regular burritos are well made. Here you can grab  your own salsa to go & as many cups as you like, unlike other places where they give you just 2 cups of salsa only.
author: Ron S.

description: This is the best Mex I've had since moving up from LA. A wonderful meal. The sauce and rice on my enchilada plate were out of this world. The atmosphere is a basic taqueria, nothing fancy.
author: Scruffy B.

description:
This is ACTUALLY the best burrito in San Francisco.

Closest competition overview:

La Taqueria: good, but overpriced, smaller, and not as delicious.
El Farolito: awesome and larger, but not as delicious.


Summary:

El Castillito is filling, cheap, delicious... and the combination of flavors just vastly out does any other burrito in the city. The fact that it's on a sketchy block with small lines and rarely in the conversation for best burrito makes it that much better.


A few notes: 

1) The church street location is good, but not quite as good.
2) Taqueria Cancun blows. Don't eat there.
3) I don't pronounce the ll as a y sound, but I think I should? sounds awkward to me.
author: Jake D.

description:
This has been my favorite taqueria in SF for twenty years. The carne asada super burrito is simply amazing, and far, far better than the same at Cancun or El Farolito. I love the fresh sliced avocado instead of guac. 

The tacos are great too, and so are the aguas frescas. The staff is always friendly and usually pretty fast. 

Love this place!
author: Richard P.

description:
Came here only for the horchata as a dessert after eating at Yamo down the street and it was too watery, not really grainy cinnamony and thicker almost as if it was not authentic. 

I'm a huge Mexican food lover though so I have yet to try any of their entrees. As for now this place is an ehhh for me because of how the horchata was. And for $3.25 for a medium cup....it coulda been better.

Only giving it more than one star than it deserves because it did satisfy my craving for some o dat horchata.
author: Kaitlyn E.

description: I came in and they where all checking me out, then the cashier asks me what kind of burrito so I start explaining and he starts ignores me and tells the guy in the back like get whatever she wants and tells me he's going to charge me for a super burrito. I get my burrito and got back to school when the beans where not cooked, they put hot salsa on it and it was cold, i come back couple hours later and he yells at me asking me why I didn't call or come right after I seen that. And when I was in line there were 3 lady's who were ordering but they gave them bad service so they left. I should of done the same. Never again .
author: Reyna B.

description:
Castillito
1 am
Wanted some good Mexican food but this wasn't very good nothing special and it was cold
author: Bai Z.

description: Best taqueria in the mission!! Expect a rowdy drunk crowd on the weekend!
author: Jyoti P.

description:
Everyone has their personal burrito preference in the mission and these guys are mine. 

Pros:
- Fast as hell. You will be in and out while your friend who insisted on going to Pancho Villa is still in line. 
- Salsa is great. I get many cups of the red chunky one. 
- Meat is good, tortillas aren't the cheap kind. If I wanted to eat bland tortillas from a store I wouldn't be in SF. 
- Always some sort of movie or football game on the tv. 

Cons:
- Loud ass jukebox is occasionally on. 
- You are certainly on the wrong side of this block. Expect the local flavor to make an appearance.
author: Scott T.

description:
I'd just finished a 6pm yoga class at sunroom yoga, and was dreaming of a delicious burrito. However, walking down Mission st, the first 2 taquerias I passed had very long lines, and no place to sit. 
Walking past El Castillito, I was surprised to see no lines, and plenty of seats available. 
So I got a Chicken burrito, wet -- which means it had cheese and enchilada sauce poured over the top. 
I loved it; small but great fresh salsa bar; the habanero salsa was perfect and made the burrito scrumptious. 
Also ordered a slice of Flan (Mexican custard) -- its about a 3.5/5. 
Still not sure why this place is so empty . . definitely worth it if you dont want to wait in lines!
author: Ros F.

description: As a Mexican, I'm always looking for authentic Mexican food while traveling. I found this place and was pleasantly impressed. I had the 2-taco plate (adobada and asada) which comes with rice and beans. It was delicious! The horchata was excellent and the chips and salsa were good too. The price for a San Francisco taco shop was about average.
author: Dan D.

description: My friend and I went here last night and I am still nauseous thinking about the experience. My friend wasn't eating so she ordered a large fresh squeezed orange juice. As she was drinking it, she kept sensing that it had a lot of pulp in it. When only 1/3 of the drink was left she opened the lid just to check it out. I kid you not, there were 4 dead fruit flies chilling on the surface of her drink. Not to mention how many more were in the drink itself (and how many she ate prior). This is DISGUSTING and this place seriously needs a health code check ASAP. I am beyond appalled that a SF establishment (with semi good reviews too) is a joke.
author: Naseem K.

description: This place puts a lot of chopped onions that are small enough to be a big pain to sort through but big enough to taste and bite into.  Remember to tell them no onions if you are not a big raw white onion fan.  Even though they do put fresh avocados in their burritos too, I prefer El Farolito over this place.  The green verde sauce was not bad but not as spicy as I would like.
author: Chris L.

description:
What is it with me and my late night eats? it's doing serious damage to my waistline and I almost never crave Mexican food late night, but I just couldn't go home on an empty stomach. 

After wandering around the Mission (BTW: never a good idea if you're walking alone at night, especially on this block) we saw the bright yellow sign for El Castillito and headed in for some Mexican eats. 

I was eyeing the quesadilla that night: carne asada with the works. Sour cream, avocado, salsa, jalapenos. Ai-yai-yai come to mama!

Served hot. Freshly prepared. Thin flour tortilla. Tender steak. Creamy avocado.  Their chips are on the thick side and they have a salsa bar. As I took one bite after another of my quesadilla, I remember how good it felt having such simple, but delicious ingredients mark the ending of a fun night.  

Just watch out for the crazy crackheads outside the door.
author: Janice C.

description:
Came to this place after having a few tacos elsewhere.....

I had the tripa, cabeza, and lengua....all were tasty and well made, the tripa was nice and crispy....

only beef is the fact that I haven't found a decent green salsa in the entire bay area....HELP!!!!
author: Raheem P.

description: The quesadillas are alright, I didn't buy anything but still got free chips and their salsa is pretty bomb. It's alright I guess, more of a cheapy hole in the wall place. This one girl fainted and like freaky shit went down but besides that it was pretty good, I'd stop there again if I had too.
author: Sophie Z.

description:
Holy crap this place was loud. The moment we stepped foot into the door the jukebox was blaring music as if it was happy to see you. The music stopped for some intervals, but it was playing loudly for the most part. Don't come here if you're trying to catch up with a friend. You might not even be able to hear your friend speak.

I ordered a breakfast burrito, and it came out to just under $6. What was I thinking? I already had a breakfast burrito one day before on the other side of the Bay. Guess I'm a sucker for eggs and meat. 

The burrito was quite large and ate half of it before realizing that I would not be able to eat until many hours later if I had finished the whole thing. There was plenty of eggs (I believe 3 eggs) and meat inside. Very worth it!

Each customer received a complimentary side of nachos and there was a salsa bar.
author: Jason T.

description:
This place is deceptively delicious - best burrito I've had in San Francisco by far.

If you go, get the wet burrito. It's huge (I could only eat half). It comes covered with some really tasty red sauce, melted cheese, guacamole, and avocados. SO GOOD.
author: Caitlin W.

description:
The cliche should be: avoid plagues like the Castillito.

Food is mediocre but cheap enough. The place is loud and uncomfortable at times. All of which would be forgivable, but they've screwed up my order for the last time. I always get it to go, and seriously about half the time I bite into a burrito to find that they've screwed up the order and it's too late to go back. This is over more than a dozen visits in the last couple years.

The visit that spurred this review, I even asked "can I get it without XYZ" twice (not in a rude way, but he didn't seem to hear me the first time), the guy says "okay" both times, and they STILL screwed it up.

Sometimes they're okay. Sometimes they're lousy. But for crying out loud it's the Mission: walk a block in any direction and you'll find a burrito place that can at least get your order right.

All in all: El Castillito just isn't worth it.
author: Al S.

description:
A friend is forcing me to write this review, although I maintain that I'm currently underqualified.  Last night we landed in this taqueria and I pulled an ultimate drunk doofus move by running down the demi-waiter dude to claim a burrito that turned out to be NOT mine.  Joke's on me cause it was a veggie burrito without salsa.  Who even ORDERs that at 2 am?  That's a 10 am yoga-mat-toting move.  Rating this place based on that order is like critiquing the Sistene Chapel from the outside (kind of boxy, but digging the monochrome!).   

The restaurant is small, but had seats for everyone.  The service was quick and the food was warm.  Pro tip: You're expected to bus your own table.  Like assholes, we tried to leave our mess on the table and some metal dude kindly suggested we clean up our mess.  Then he told us to fuck off.  Right away, sir.  

This place is nothing to write home about, but it's open late and has aiiiight grub.
author: Ellen C.

description: Good place if it is after midnight and your in the mission and want decent food.  Beware the falling down drunks or at least plan on assisting said drunks with menu selection (It's hard to read when you have the spins).
author: John C.

description:
This place is open until 2am on the weekdays when other local taquerias are not-- super sweet for those drunchies after Skylark on a Monday-- or whatever else you're doing in the Mission that late Mon-Thurs.

The guys working here are ridiculously nice-- really helpful, making everything fresh even at 1:55-- and yes, if you manage to get past all of those cracked out crazies they will not deny you service even at 1:59am. And on top of that they know when to muscle one of those crazies out of the place if need be.

Me and a semi-vegetarian friend ordered a regular cheese quesadilla, nachos sans meat add refried beans, and 2 chicken tacos.

The QUESADILLA was shockingly good-- they use the good kinda cheese that is stringy and doesnt separate easily. Thin, wonderfully soft flour tortilla. (would have never usually ordered this but would order this here again.)

TACOS- plain and simple, corn tortilla w/ moist chicken, tasty salsa and and cheap.  My veggie friend even took some bites.

NACHOS- despite the fact that this is actually not mexican food there was a table of mexican men around a plate of these at a table nearby and i get why.  Lots of sour cream, lots of avocado, lots of all the right stuff and everything made to order. Devoured. (again, not a usual order but would absolutely go back for these.)

Tiny place, but they have a salsa bar? and all 3 salsas are delish? AWESOME. free chips? AWESOME.  Take a friend, stay close while you maneuver your way down the street-- and throw these guys a good tip.
author: Tiffany W.

description: I live right across the street so I usually come here to get a burrito. Its affordable and service is quick and easy.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Whenever I am in the mission running errands, I stop in here for take-away tacos.  They are great.  The service is good and the folks working there are very nice.  
I always get the same thing: Super Tacos with Carnitas and we make two meals from them.  They heat nicely in the microwave the next day. They are also not at all stingy with the avocados, which make the dish.
I have never eaten inside and must admit, I would hesitate to do so.  I am a bit of a clean freak when it comes to my eating establishments, and the dining area just doesn't look that inviting.
The only thing I would like to see is a mild option for the salsa or perhaps a fresh pico de gallo.  I am not a fan of super hot foods and their salsa is a bit much for me.  I know there are folks who love the 4 alarm condiment, so it would be great if they could have options.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: In my opinion, best Al Pastor in SF. I like the all meat burritos and nachos.
author: Ameer N.

description: Went there today as I was strolling through San Francisco and got the veggie burrito. The burrito was tasty, tightly rolled and the red chunky salsa I got was hot and flavorful. Definitely beats Chipotle haha
author: Sean A.

description:
**VEGETARIAN REVIEW**

Great place in the Mission for cheap, tasty, and filling tacos. The place sometimes gets a little shady at night. 

I've only had tacos here. A super veggie taco is about $3 and comes with 2 corn tortillas, cheese, beans (black or pinto), rice, lettuce, and tomatoes. There is a salsa bar near the cashier with green and red salsa and pico de gallo.
author: Geetanjali J.

description:
I was in The Mission for a show and needed a quick dinner.  After walking by El Castillito and pulling up the Yelp review I decided to check it out.  A couple of the tables were occupied but it wasn't full by any means.

The man behind the counter greeted us right away.  I made a quick decision and put in my order.  He wasn't thrown off when I ordered in Spanish and was kind enough to respond back in Spanish (many places will look at me and just reply back in English).

I would say the thing I enjoyed most about El Castillito was their chunkier house salsa.  It had a nice kick and more robust flavor than most places.  I tried three tacos, 1 al pastor, 1 carne asada, and 1 pollo.  I have to admit they weren't super tasty.  Slightly on the bland side to the point that there wasn't much different flavor between the different meats.  

Does anyone know if they are more known for the seafood items?  Perhaps I need to try that next time...
author: Christopher W.

description: I rolled to Taqueria El Castillito after the YEE at Public Works. I was famished and needed some Grub. Its a basic Mexican restuarant spartanly furnished with a LCD playing Futbol. I ordered a  Wet Al Pastor Burritto which contains-Rice, Beans,Onions,Cilantro,Melted Cheese,Sour Cream,Avocado,Topped with Red and Green Sauce and Al Pastor. It was ready in 8 minutes flat and the Cashier brought it out to me. It was a Big Burrito and very tasty Im a Fan.
author: Eugene L.

description:
Felt pretty clean, though plenty shady. There was no shortage of hobos inside unloading their belongings on the surrounding tables as they glared and gawked at us while we ate.

My quesadilla castillito (I still have a hard time pronouncing it) was humongous and decadent, filled will plenty of meat and extras but it was very leaky. It was sort of a half finger food and half scoop out the innards kind of wrap, still no short of delicious. The carnitas tasted different, more chunky than pulled consistency, with plenty of grease and solid cubes of fat to pick out, but good nonetheless.

What's up with the chips? You only get like 4 served in a small paper trough. WTF.

Overall, not bad. We only went in because we parked immediately in front, though I think I prefer Cancun.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
I come here during my lunch hour with a friend who can't handle spicy food. She likes this place because they're not spicy...

Their pastor is really good. I'm not a huge fan of pastor but I really like theirs. Their burritos are pretty bland and sometimes oddly oily and greasy.

My only real complaint here is that there's just no spice! They have a salsa bar too, and none of that's spicy which isn't any good. 

Their agua frescas are grossly sweet. Save your money and drink water or buy a coke.
author: Vanessa F.

description: Open late, clean, fast, cheap, and not a burger place. Full salsa bar and bright setting. Worth a try for Burrito lovers.
author: R C.

description:
I love this place! It's at a great location, it TAKES CARDS (Taqueria Cancun's greatest weakness), and it makes great al pastor burritos! The staff are also very nice and friendly to me, and take the weird, intense area in stride! It's also usually not crowded and the service is very fast, which is great in contrast to the insanity of Cancun.

There are some problems; some of the cashiers don't understand English too well (not a problem for me, but if you have complicated instructions, a few Spanish words might help), and their carnitas burritos aren't as good as their al pastor or carne asada ones. Also, 16th and Mission is pretty crazy so there are often crazy people wandering around outside who sometimes come inside and try to sell people hair dryers. The staff deals with these people well, however.

Overall, I highly recommend this place!
author: Ned D.

description:
Have an agenda.

A corner of town you need to know exactly what you are doing. No pausing to figure out your next move. No standing around wondering where to get food. You need an agenda.

I walked in hungry. Guy at the register couldn't have been nicer. Accommodated all additions and subtractions. Left about five minutes later with a burrito weighing me down with grilled chicken, plenty of black beans, lettuce at no charge and salsa. Dinner agenda fulfilled. 

First bite confirmed what I expected. This location is just as good as the others in the city. Comes with adventure on the side at no additional charge.
author: Jason B.

description: Good, solid taqueria. Awesome veggie choices and decent salsa. I've opted for tacos and nachos, and both are good.
author: Amber K.

description:
This review is brought to you by the letter H. 
H as in "Hella."

1 am. Everyone in this joint is hella suspect. Hella sketchy. I know it's part of the late night Mexican food in the Mission experience, but it is especially unnerving at this particular joint, even for a native San Franciscan like me. Trust, I'm used to hella unsavory ass characters, but the creep factor here is turned up way past 10.

Plus, I'm hella bitter that I ordered my veggie burrito "wet." Instead of a buttery enchilada sauce like at every other taqueria, this one was more of a mole sauce (I hate mole sauce.) Mole sauce all over my "veggie" burrito (I guess rice & beans constitutes as a veggie burrito.) I was not amused. 

My dining partner was super pleased with his two tacos (i know one was carne asada, can't remember the meat in the other.)

The monetary damage was small: $17 for the above mentioned foods plus a Jarritos & an agua fresa (sweet strawberry drink, not watered down) but the damage done to my mood was monumental. 

Cash only. 

P.S. as irritated as I was that #1, we didn't just take our food to-go & #2, I did not enjoy my burrito, I have to say that the guy who took our order was hella friendly, like the best service I've ever gotten at a taqueria.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Tacos could use more heat in the meat, but decent. It's located in a dodgier bubble of the Mission, so there's that. Place smelled a bit like a homeless shelter and had that grimy glean to it too. Don't think I'll be back , considering how there are so many other taco places available.
author: Kevin L.

description: The Chicken Burrito was okay, but definitely not as good as El Farolito's.
author: Dipesh G.

description:
This is where we cheat at.  Yes, you heard right, we are cheaters, my hubby and I.  We're in constant strive to be freakin' healthy, but on our weak days, we come running and running pretty damn fast.  The reasons?

#1 They know us so well, we don't have to order, order.  The cashier just say, "The usual?"  Hubby nods and pays.  And our order shows up after we helped ourselves with #2 all the salsas we desired.

#3 Super Steak Burrito - Big beefy flavor with all the fixings. His fave.
#4 Quesadila El Castillito - Chicken with avocado, pickled jalapeno, and oozy creamy cheese.  My fave.
#5 The chips are good and not greasy.  Thick, but not too thick.

Enough for guilt for the whole week, but oh so devilishly delicious.  The party you shouldn't have, but our mouths beg for it.
author: Vanna S.

description: Weird, thought I reviewed this place already. I go there once a week! I love their chicken tacos and my man always gets their steak or carnitas quesadilla or burrito. They take credit/debit cards too and have a good beer selection. Plus their salsa is tasty. Please not that they do not have guacamole! Only avocado!
author: Nicole O.

description: ok! where can you to buy food on Tuesday midnight? Misssion! That's awesome! Well, I DOUBTED  about to eat here, but I decided to do it, not so many options to pick at that time, but I need to say the carnitas super burrito was really really good, and the people was really friendly.
author: Carmen D.

description:
Aside from my recent Quesadilla kick, I've also been heavily involved in this long-delayed highly-anticipated blockbuster-sequel-esque love affair. With Cinnamon.

For so long, I ran away from Cinnamon like he was a giant can of SlimFast and I was Camryn Manheim. I regret it, but the time apart has been good for us. It's made our love-making all the more sweeter... more passionate... more flavorful...

I've been dashing Ground Cinnamon on everything: coffee, cereal, my fingers, PBJ sandwiches, through the snow on a one-horse open sleigh, etc. etc.

I am inherently a better man because of the Cinnamon in me. Another thing inherently greater for the same reason is the famed Mexican drink of tradition, horchata. 

And I've found a great place for inexpensive, creamy, refreshing, cinnamony horchata.

I didn't know the name of this place so I had to do a Search on Yelp. 

For Janet's sakes, Searching for "Mexican Restaurant" in the "Mission District" is like trying to find false eyelashes stuck on a drag queen's wig!

After clicking on a bunch of the tiny little triangles with numbers on them, I finally found the one. El Uno, if you will.

El Castillito. I believe this translates roughly to "The Castle... Lito" which I think is the most perfect way to describe this place.
author: Joshua L.

description:
3.5 stars for their burritos.  I haven't had anything else but their burritos but since it's around the corner from me?  Good chance I'll have more to write about later.

Not the best pollo asado burrito, but, the pollo en salsa roja is delicious.  I've gone there determined to try the pastor, the carne but when it's crunch time I just can't help myself.  The juicy, lip-licking seasoned salsa roja chicken calls to me, and I must obey.  

They give you tons of chips with your burrito and they have a salsa bar, so if you're not starving and are a chip muncher, you're going to have half a leftover slab to take away.

Agua frescas are pretty good, too.
author: Ben S.

description:
This restaurant is in my old hood, and I was a regular before departing for Paris. 

The food is solid, and I love their tomatillo salsa. Service is reliably good. 

Thing is, is that if you decide to eat here after 1 or 2am on any weekend night, this place seems to attract and cater to homeless people and crack addicts. There have been accusations that the men behind the counter are selling the goods, and I've seen a few things that makes me think that's the case. They don't ask this crowd to leave, even though they're not eating and smoking crack inside of the restaurant. 

Definitely sketch late-night, but solid for tacos al pastor during the daytime hours.
author: julia k.

description:
Wow, I have such mixed feelings. It's in the Mission and this neighborhood is what I call ghetto chic. There are really nice parts and there are REALLY ghetto parts. I usually don't venture out to the questionable areas because I'm a wimp and I don't wanna be asking for it.. Being an averaged sized and directionless Asian girl doesn't help either. Though, I still think I've done my fair share of "ghetto dining", this place was up there on the level of gHeTtO-NeSs.

I....yes I actually picked this place for dinner based on a friend's request for Mexican. I totally ignoring other yelpers' reviews about it being ghetto. How bad could it be? I'm from Richmond! Pssh...

My stars are for the food alone. My carne asada super burrito was actually very delicious. It was also cheap ($5) and huge! It came with your choice of meat, avocado, cheese, onions, hot salsa, and beans. I thought it was actually a nice change up for them to use avocado slices instead of guacamole. But I really lost my appetite thanks to the crackheads lurking outside, homeless (or just dirty..?) people loitering in the place, random thugs smokin' it up, and a big scary dude having some Jerry Springer moments with his woman. I was so scared he was going to start eyeing us!

My friend and I had a conversation online about this later that night. I think this snippet basically sums it up:

me: that place was HELLA ghetto dude.. 
me: werent u scared 
friend: fo realz, um a lil when that man hella yelled at his bitch! shooo 
that was just dam... calm down yo 
me: LOL 
friend: but dam it was GOOD shite! mmmm!

Shout out to my three homies who accompanied me! :P
author: Julia T.

description:
This is a special entry dealing mostly with service... but don't be deceived... the food was great too =)

How many times have we been drunk and totally left our credit cards at the bar, coats at the check, sanity at the bottom of the bottle, etc in the wake of our craziness?!.. For me it has been too many... 

After one particular night, I lost my purse which included a whole lot of important stuff. In particular, my identification and cell phone which were essential because I was celebrating that night because I just got a job and started that Monday!

I go through my entire night... 1 restaurant, 4 bar/clubs, and right now... my most favorite taqueria ever!!! It's a little after 3 am and I'm making hand gestures to a guy sweeping the floor of the taqueria as I desperately try to remember Spanish for "purse" (I never regretted taking French in HS till that day). The guy puts on the biggest smile and gets all excited... runs to the back of the restaurant and comes back with my purse!!! I was so happy I gave him a big ol' hug and whatever cash was in there.

Not only did this restaurant have some of the best carnitas and al pastor and awesome salsa for my drunkness (I've been going here for 4 years now)... they also have some honest and responsible patrons and staff!!

Keep honest places in business!!
author: Joanna L.

description:
The only taqueria I bother with.  My holy grail. The Pastor tacos are amazing - just meat, hot sauce, cilantro, and onions.  My mouth is watering just writing these words.  Also love the grilled chicken super burrito - I can almost never finish it, they're huge, and really good.  I love their salsa - I wish like hell they'd sell it to go in a six or twelve ounce container, cos  I'd pay whatever they wanted  for it.  Damn, I wish I'd gone there for dinner tonight.

El Castillito  ftw :)
author: Mer L.

description:
I'm kinda sick of Pancho Villa and finally forced my girl to try Taqueria El Castillito that day. We came in during lunch hours, and everybody who were there was either hispanic or male. Cockfest~ blargh.

But, the servers were really friendly! 

I tried Tortas. it was aight. It's like a Burrito without rice, beans, and the burrito wrap.
author: Miss C.

description: Most mexican food tastes absolutely delicious to me when I'm drunk, and I think this can apply to a lot of people I know personally and beyond. So when we came in here after 2am, I got the quesadilla suiza, and I must be honest...I really wasn't all that impressed. I thought it was rather bland and so was the salsa...yeah kinda lame. But there are so many other good reviews for this place I may have to try it again...after all I used to really love the Church st location...
author: Lauren S.

description: Yum!!! :-) I just had the best super taco here. Can't wait to come back. Hot, super fresh, lots of flavor, friendly service.
author: B W.

description:
Disgusted on multiple levels with this dump.

Went there on a late Sunday night after flying back into town.  The cashier was either drunk or on something.  Ordered a simple burrito, then proceeded to watch as various folks who came in after me and order get their food almost instantly, while I still sat there waiting.  When I asked when I could expect my burrito, the cashier looked at me like I was crazy or something.  Ohhhhhhhhh, it finally hit him!  Didn't even apologize for whatever mix-up there was.  

I then watched as the cook put the chicken on the grill, for literally 15 seconds, dump all this crap I didn't ask for and don't like (sour cream, avocado, cheese, etc).  He then gave me the burrito.  I opened it up, and it looked like the worst piece of sh!t I have ever seen.  I tasted one of the pieces of chicken, and it was still cold.  WTF?  I just left the dump, didn't even feel like arguing with the drunk/drugged cashier about getting my $6 back.  At that point, I just wanted to get the hell out of this dump.  My experience is diametrically the opposite of another person who claims this is the best taqueria in SF or the world.  I have several other places that I would recommend before ever fathoming the possibility of setting foot in this dump ever again.

Stay away, there are much better options out there.
author: Rolando P.

description: Got the carnitas regular burrito today. The burrito as a whole was on the dry side, and the meat had definitely been pan fried twice. Wouldn't go back.
author: Brian Q.

description:
It ain't fancy.  It ain't hoity toity.  There be crack dealers outside and a massage parlor next door . . . but the corn tortilla quesadilla with chicken knocked my socks off.  Literally.  I left my socks in El Castillito.

Plus they've got a cute little Yelp sign by the cash register.
author: Joe C.

description:
I don't know what it is lately, but I have had about 5 people just start talking to me in Spanish this week, then look at me strangely when I say I don't speak the language. 

Maybe its because I always seem to be in the Taquerias ordering "Un Carne Asada super burrito, ningun arroz, la salsa caliente, por favor". I am really good at saying that, even when I am slurring. 

The man who helps me here always talks to me in Spanish. No matter how many times I tell him I don't understand, he doesn't seem to believe me. I am pretty sure he is telling me the following;

- I am happy you are not a crackhead
- Don't let the crackheads steal your change on the way out
- Don't let the crackheads swipe your burrito, which is better than most in the Mission, by the way
- We grill our burritos, don't steam them
- you are ruining our profit margin by requesting no rice in your burrito, but you are cute so its okay
- Eat the green salsa, though it is not muy caliente it is f*ckin good
 
And something dirty I just cant repeat here.........

They use avocado instead of guacamole, pinto beans instead of re fried and add cilantro to their burritos. A little different, but good nonetheless.

They are open later on school nights than the other Taquerias nearby.
author: Drue C.

description:
BEST TAQUERIA IN SAN FRANCISCO, if not all of California... Love you, El Castillo, Love you LOOOOONG time.

By recommendation from a happy Kurdish chick named Rosie, my friends and I wandered in here late night on a Wednesday, to find a huge line and a big Al Pastor spit gleaming away... 

The Horchata was TO DIE FOR, the Torta del Pastor was mouth-watering, the chips were perfect, and the servings were generous. Affordable, delicious, and undeniably authentic.

Other pluses:
- Incredible friendly, funny, and happy service
- Action-packed juke-box (play the "El Burracho" one)
- An ATM for all you cash-challenged folk.

GO HERE. You won't ever wanna leave.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Great place if you can make it there in one piece.  You're gonna have to watch all 4 directions for speeding cars, psycho bikers, and street thugs.  I think it's located in one of the most awkward intersections of SF.

But once you get through the thicket, the place isn't that bad.  The people in there are cool.  You can watch them cook - and you can check out the items before they cook to determine it's freshness.  

They lay on the meats pretty fresh.  Unfortunately, the carne asada tacos were just par.  As you can see, there is a bin of pre-cooked beef.  So, of course, how good can that be?  The pork burrito, however, was pretty darn good.  Tender and juicy.

People are nice.  The place is eh so-so clean.  More like a pick up and go type joint.  There's a lot of room in there - 8 tables maybe.  But it just has that gloomy office bad lighting set-up.  Plus a lot of shadows.  I don't like shadows.
author: Isaac L.

description:
Everytime i'm in the mission i seem to stop here.  even if you're not hungry it's a good stop.

A taco is about $2.30. Practically a meal. lots of meat. Carnitas is a good choice. piled onto 2 corn tortillas. cilantro and so juicy and flavorful. 

i love the molded plastic orange and yellow seats. it's like i'm in a 1985 mexican cafeteria. 

plus you can get a bottle of beer or a jarritos for cheap.
author: Tim O.

description:
I'll start with the reason I deducted a star; the locale can be intimidating.  Adrienne G. pretty much summed up the daily landscape that is Mission & 17th Sts.  But on to the fare.

This is one of my top 3 burrito places in the City (La Corneta & Chunky's).  Sarah s. (see below) called it with the freshness of the ingredients and the grilling of the tortilla.  Best part is they do it right every single time I've been there.  These hombre's are consistent.  I've had the carnitas, carne asada, and pollo burritos and they all kick ass.

Forget the lines at that one on 16th Street.  Drop by here instead.
author: Pete M.

description:
I like! 

I like that the line is never more than 7-10 people. 

I like the jukebox selection (Selena, yes please)!

I like that a huge, fabulous veggie burrito is $4.60

I like the salsa they have!

I like that I forgot where it was but found it the other night like the big, yellow holy grail of taquerias that it is!

*no credit/debit cards but they have an atm machine for your/their convenience.
author: Molly G.

description:
My favorite Taqueria of all time.  I started coming here back in High School and have never looked back.  I've tried many places over the years but have always come back here when I wanted the best tasting burritos and a whole avocado stuffed inside at a fair price.  I pretty much get the Al Pastor (Marinated Meat) every time I come here.  It's acddictive you know.  

And though the surroundings can be shady on certain nights here, you always have the option to eat it to go.  What I do like is that the prices are pretty fair when you compare it to other better known taquerias in the area like El Toro and Pancho Villa.  I mean I hate having to pay like $8-$9 for a Super Burrito.  Just don't seem right.....
author: Mark W.

description:
If you can get past the fact that you're walking through drug deals, crackheads, and crazies alike, you're in for a treat!

I was DYING for some good Mexican food and boy did I find it.  It was so delicious and I plan on going back again soon.  I ordered the Tamales and they were wonderful.  The refried beans had just the right amount of salt and flavor.  The rice was wonderful and the Corona wahsed it all down jusssttttt riiiiiggghhhhttt... 

Get over the fact that it's in the HOOD and GO FOR IT!  YUM!
author: Noneya B.

description:
The best chicken tacos in town - the regular ones that is.
O. D. liked the super tacos with beans, cheese and avocado as well.
Can't comment on anything else here but the chicken tacos are well worth the trip.
author: billy M.

description:
Came here on a hungover Saturday for some pre-Bay-to-Breakers costume search fuel.  We got the quesadilla that ate Manhattan... more like a three-month-old-infant-sized grilled burrito than a quesadilla.  

We shared it four ways, using a newspaper stand in front of Thirft Town as our table.  Now that's class.
author: Sarah J.

description:
El Castillito has what has to be the greasiest carnitas in San Francisco.  The grease ran down the side of the burrito, pooling in the tinfoil.  My hands were still shiny after a stack of napkins.  This is both good and bad, but mostly bad.   Add the over-zealousness with sour cream, and the fact that the salsa fresca is way hotter than anyone else's (this is definitely good), and El Castillito = rough night ahead.  

The Mission branch of El Castillito does not have much in veggie options -- no roasted veggies, no tofu, only rice & beans.  

All that said, El Castillito is still better than Cancun, and better than a large number of joints in the area.
author: Ben A.

description:
El Castillito, especially this location, has some great tacos. If tacos are all you're thinking about and not the overall eating experience then this restaurant is fantastic.  this is especially the case if you absolutely love al pastor or carnitas.  Their employees have seen it all and they're located in kind of a crappy area... They're pretty much the only thing open late on that part of 18th St.  

Pros:  tacos, especially carnitas and al pastor
Cons: location, more "finesse entrees" -- seek these out at the Church St. location instead.
author: Jaime R.

description:
OH MY GOD
I don't know who this guy "Al Pastor" is, but he makes one hell of a burrito.  

He sure doesn't work at Gordo, which is unfortunate because I live in the Richmond.  Now I must go to the Mission to enjoy TASTY burros when the mood strikes.  This is not too difficult, since they're open late (we were there on a recent Wednesday at 10:00 pm.)

Typical Mexican fare:  taco taco, taco burrito, platos, burritos, agua fresca, fresh squeezed jugos, and I saw a delicious-looking flan on the counter, but after that monster-sized burro, there was certainly no room left.
author: Ken B.

description:
Food
I confess that my only experience is with their vegetarian burritos, which are mighty fine. Their salsa is wonderful! Medium spicy and the chilies are just a bit sweet, giving it a uniquely good flavor. Everything else about the burrito is just fine, but the salsa really stands out. They also have a nice selection of additional salsas. Good stuff!

Service
Every time I go here the guy who runs the cash register is friendly and calm, even when dealing with difficult customers. I go there about once a week and he knows my usual order - rings it up without even asking :-)
author: Erik F.

description:
Pastor super burrito was mexicanlicious, but honeyB's pastor wet burrito made me jealous it was bigger and served on a plate with tons of sauce; It was prettier. The marinated pork is definitely the way to go!
filling and not 90% rice, we hate that. More meat I say!

my only con is the spicy sauce they use is more like chile oil, which just made the back of my throat feel like spicy vaseline.
so I went to the salsa bar and saturated it in chipotle salsa.mmmm
author: Breezy M.

description:
This would be my favorite burrito joint in the city if it weren't for the neighborhood. I'm no snob, I live a block away but the crack heads, meth addicts, and strung out prostitutes will eventually get to you. To be honest, I only order burritos so I have no idea how their other dishes are but their burritos are AWESOME!

Their tortillas are heated on a griddle--not steamed! Their meat is tasty and clean (though it doesn't have the grilled flavor of some of the more expensive taquerias), their salsa bar is yummy, and you can get a delicious burrito for less than $5.00! I don't know what it is but their burritos are SO tasty--some of the best. And you can afford to eat here every night!
author: Mario T.

description:
I'm going out on a limb and saying just on food quality...5 stars.  This place has the best Mexican bbq pork in the city.  It's just that good.

Large quantity for the price.  Awesome aqua frescas.  Awesome quesidillas.  Awesome burritos across the board.

The place is surrounded by crack hookers and some pretty uncool characters, so don't bring your mom... unless she's a crack hooker.
author: Ben M.

description:
Wow. I used to frequent the church location but never never again. Its worth the extra 10 block walk which you'll need anyway if you're planning on ordering the carnitas but now that I have transportation again, no matter. The service is way friendlier and the juke box doesn't always 
come on without fail when I sit down. The cheese is way better here! I'm as asada quesadilla guy myself. May I reccommend the Castillito Quesadilla. And the salsa variety is a major plus!!!
author: eric m.

description:
A friend and I journeyed over to the Mission to get haircuts the other day, and by the time we left the salon (check it out: Pirate Salon), we had worked up a ravenous appetite for cheap Mexican food. The huge "TAQUERIA" sign out front of El Castillito lured us in, and minutes later, we were happily chowing down on what were probably the biggest burritos I've ever gotten at a restaurant. 

I had the Super Burrito with carne asada - it was, to put it quite simply, big and delicious (that's what she said... haha, sorry, I couldn't resist throwing that in there!). It was really exactly what I needed. The cashier was also really friendly and helpful, and the salsa was decent. I could only eat about half of my burrito there, so I took the rest home with me and had it for dinner, too - still tasted just as good the second time around. I will definitely be coming back the next time I'm in the area.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Had an al pastor wet burrito that was amazing. Salsa bar also amazing. Staff was super friendly. Wish I lived closer.
author: Ryan G.

description: it was aite, i wanted chorizo but i needed to share so i got chorizo on my nachos which i know is wierd but it came out pretty good. They def overcooked the chorizo in some parts but i was still pretty satisfied. All the stuff my friends got turned out better, ie burrito's and tacos so i guess the moral of the story is don't get chorizo on your nachos
author: Misha T.

description:
It's a Tuesday night, and we were craving a burrito all day. We were dancing at BOC, so afterwards at 1:30AM  we were desperate for any taqueria open late to satisfy our burrito cravings. After walking down awkwardly sketchy streets, past drunks and crackheads, we stumbled upon this place at 17th and Mission.

I got the super asada burrito. OMG -- I was either really really drunk or the burrito was amazing. My friends, who were not nearly as drunk as I was, all but orgasmed as they ate their burritos. It was thick, girthy, juicy, and beefy. The guacamole was more like half an entire avocado sliced and thrown into the beautifully harmonized symphony of sour cream, beans, rice, pico de gallo, and LOADS of CARNE!!!! They were arranged in such a way that as I worked my way down, there was an equal distribution of everything. No awkward chunks.

The down side: 1) nasty guys outside the window making kissy faces, 2) walking past crackheads on the way there, 3) crackheads came in toward the end of our meal and starting shouting at each other, getting more aggressive and on the brink of a fight, 4) crackheads and thugs on the way out which meant we split a cab rather than wait for the muni.
author: Pris C.

description:
I had the super carnitas taco. It was delicious and just filling enough. The place is very cold inside so you have to eat with your jacket on if
you don't get it to go. Also in a very questionable/dicey neighborhood.
The funny part is the chips. They give you these teeny, tiny ,mini cardboard containers of corn chips which is enough for about 3 bites. I did ask for another round of chips and it was no problem. The 3 types of salsa are all very good. I'll be back for another one of those tasty tacos.
author: Cindy J.

description:
1. Cheap, cheap prices.  
2.  With salsa bar.  And... 
3.  The salsa bar containers are twice the volume as those at Pancho Villa!!   

This is my special, little favorite taqueria.  But it's in a really, really bad part of Mission Street.  Only during the daytime do I see a customer in here who isn't either a pimp or a local Mission Latino and it's all because of the location on the western sidewalk of Mission, much too close to the crack-infested squalor at the 16th St. BART, but not quite close enough to 18th to bring in a "whiter" clientele.  

And that's just fine with me.  Low profile, low prices.  

Super Veggie Taco:  $2.44 !  and you get chips!  

And damn straight, you better believe they got the best salsa in the inner-Mission!   Geez Louise, how I love their salsa.

If the crackheads scare ya, just walk fast.    ; )
author: Theresa W.

description:
Being raised off of mexican food, my friends and I found this restaurant to be especially delicious. The people were really friendly and were ready to pick up our plates as soon as were were done. The proportions were huge for everything we got and they still had high quality flavors. Atop from the salsa bar, the salsa incorporated in the foods don't burn your mouth with spices, but compliment the food with flavor. 

In summary: 
Good Food
Good Prices
Good Service

Fore warning: The internet jukebox doesn't work, it WILL eat your quarters.
author: Manny D.

description:
I was expecting good things of El Castillito, given that it ticked the usual boxes for a good Mexican eating establishment: in the kind of area you wouldn't want to visit alone at night, grotty plastic tables and chairs, and at least half of the patrons having a distinctly druggie look to them. I went for the camarones a la diabla and was looking forward to some devillishly spicy prawns! I think there must have been some kind of mix up in the kitchen, as the prawns I got seemed to be a la Heinz - the sauce looked and tasted suspiciously ketchup-y, and it certainly wasn't hot. The rest of the dish was pretty so-so, although the unmelted cheese on top of the beans wasn't greatly appetizing. The service was pretty friendly, though, and the mild salsa was tasty -- it's a shame they don't do a hot version of the same recipe.

Might give it another try, but won't be having that dish again!
author: Amelia I.

description:
NOTE:  READ DISCLAIMERS

DISCLAIMER#1:  I have an emotional attachment to this place dating back over 15 years.
DISCLAIMER#2:  This is in a GHETTO neighborhood, and you may fear for your safety.  LIke SERIOUSLY.

of over 100 tacquerias i've been to in San Francisco, I think EC is the best.

Why?

Same guys always working there, green salsa is incredible, everything I've ever eaten here is amazing, very very good carne asada burrito.  Unfortunately I occasionally fear for my life.

If you can handle pushing the hookers, crackheads, and aggressively panhandling smelly homeless guys out of the way to get in (it's right next to the nasty gross porno store and the crack hotel), it is INCREDIBLE

I recommend the Super Burrito with Carne Asada.
author: thomas g.

description: After a night of drinking, the chorizo super burrito is like a gift from heaven.  This is my favorite late night burrito spot in the whole city.
author: Jori P.

description:
Mmmm burritos! I had been away for three months, so a burrito had to be had as soon as I arrived back in Sf! El Castillito served us great burritos, slightly stale chips, and yummy salsas. The green salsa is great, creamy yet garlicy.

I... want...more...
author: Ayse B.

description: The food was amazing, thought the ordering process confused me a bit.  Great people watching, fabulous super fish taco, and I loved it!  Easiest parking is at the Safeway, and then walk through one door of the store and out the other before going to the taco shop.  I usually buy something at Safeway anyway, but it's a handy trick for outmaneuvering the security guard.
author: Jamie S.

description:
Totally eat here if you want violent liquid shits!

I know I did!
author: Frankie D.

description:
Back in the day, they had "Jesus Built My Hot Rod" on the juke box, and for 5 bucks, you could get a bottle of Bud and a huge-ass urban protein tube (aka "burrito"), and watch a stray member of Snakefinger's (RIP) band fend off assorted crack-ho's, junkies, and CHUDs.

Little Castle is still bare-bones and all business, with a decent salsa bar (one of the best green sauces in town).  You can always find a seat, because all the pasty indy rock dweebs are clogging up their arteries at Can-Cun.

Viva Little Castle!
author: Scurvy D.

description:
In terms of number of times I've been here, this is my hands-down #1 spot for burritos in SF.  While my proximity to the restaurant doesn't hurt, it's really the green salsa that brings me back and back and back.  

And the (ahem) live entertainment.  

The two highlights were really slow motion drunk boxing between homeless men (the kitchen staff all came out to watch because it was so ridiculous - don't worry, none got hurt, noone landed a "punch"), and a 6-something foot postitute hoofing in on giant heels yelling about chips and salsa and then hoofing out after a brief tantrum about something unintelligible.  While I know that these are sad sights, I must admit: on some level they are so incredible, that you have to shake your head and laugh.
